transcripts.prompt: Transcribe this image as accurately as possible. Only include the text extracted from the document
transcripts.message:
Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth & State of Massachusetts, a soldier of the Revolution, and a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7, 1832, being of the age of seventy-five years, do testify & say, that I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North Bridgewater, that I have known him from our boyhood, that I was attached to a Company of Minute Men under Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April 1775 when the British marched to Lexington; I marched towards Roxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard was one. At Dorchester we were ordered to Marshfield, where we were dismissed & returned to Bridgewater, having been absent three days. Oliver Howard aforesaid was with me during said three days.
In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at Braintree or Weymouth, when an alarm was given; I then marched to the sea shore in Capt’n David Packard’s Company – was gone two days, when we were dismissed & returned home. Oliver Howard aforesaid, was with us during the two days.
In 1776, I enlisted into Capt’n Nathan Alden’s Company of Massachusetts militia in a Regiment commanded by Colo’nele Hall & Johnson, for three months, & marched to Bristol in Rhode Island, & served the full term of three months.
The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same Company during the three months, at the end of which time we were dismissed without a written discharge.

Jona'n Perkins

Commonwealth of Massachusetts
Plymouth County Ss
April 3, 1834. Then personally appears Jonathan Perkins, & subscribed the forgoing affidavit, and made oath to the truth of the same – and I further certify that said Jonathan Perkins is a man of truth & veracity.

Before me E. F. Perkins Justice of Peace

transcripts.message:
I Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County
of Plymouth & State of Massachusetts a soldier of the Revolution and
a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7, 1832,
being of the age of Seventy-five years, do testify and say, that
I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North
Bridgewater; that I have known him from our boyhood: that
I was attached to a Company of Minute men under
Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April
1775 when the British marched to Lexington: I marched towards
Roxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard
was one: at Dorchester we were ordered to Marshfield, where
we were dismissed, & returned to Bridgewater, having been
absent three days; Oliver Howard aforesaid was with me during
said three days.

In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at Braintree or
Weymouth, when an alarm was given: I then marched to the
sea shore in Capt. David Packard's Company - was gone two
days, when we were dismissed & returned home - Oliver Howard
aforesaid, was with us during the two days.

In 1776, I enlisted into Capt. Nathan Alden's Company of
Massachusetts militia in a Regiment commanded by Colo-
-nel Hall & Johnson, for three months, & marched to Bristol
in Rhode Island, & served the full term of three months.
The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same
Company during the three months, at the end of which time
we were dismissed without a written discharge.

Jon^a. Perkins

Commonwealth of Massachusetts
    Plymouth County ss.     } April 8. 1834. Then personally appeared
Jonathan Perkins, & subscribed the foregoing affidavit, and made
oath to the truth of the same - and I further certify that said Jon^a.
Perkins is a man of truth & veracity.

Before me, Jesse Perkins Justice of Peace

transcripts.message:
I Jonathan Perkins of North Bridgewater in the County of Plymouth & State of Massachusetts, a soldier of the Revolution, and a pensioner of the United States, under the Act of June 7, 1832: being of the age of seventy five years, do testify and say, that I am well acquainted with Oliver Howard of said North Bridgewater, that I have known him from our boyhood: that I was attached to a Company of Minute Men under Captain Josiah Hayden at the time of the alarm in April 1775 when the British marched to Lexington; & marched towards Roxbury with said Company, of which the said Oliver Howard was one. At Dorchester we were ordered to Marshfield, where we were dismissed, & returned to Bridgewater, having been absent three days. Oliver Howard aforesaid was with me during said three days.

In 1776 or 1777 the British landed at Braintree or Weymouth, when an alarm was given: I then marched to the sea shore in Capt. David Packard's Company—was gone two days, when we were dismissed & returned home. Oliver Howard aforesaid, was with us during the two days.

In 1776, I enlisted into Capt. Nathan Alden's Company of Massachusetts Militia in a Regiment commanded by Cols. Jos. Hall & Johnson, for three months, & marched to Bristol in Rhode Island, & served the full term of three months.

The aforesaid Oliver Howard was with me in the same Company during the three months, at the end of which time we were dismissed without a written discharge.

Jon'a Perkins

Commonwealth of Massachusetts
Plymouth County ss
April 8. 1834. Then personally appeared Jonathan Perkins, & subscribed the foregoing affidavit, and made oath to the truth of the same—and I further certify that said Jon’a Perkins is a man of truth & veracity.

Before me
Zephe Perkins Justice of Peace

transcripts.message:
Deposition of Joseph Barnett

State of Ohio, Hamilton County

On this 26th day of March A.D. one thousand eight hundred and fifty three, personally appeared before me, a Notary Public in and for the aforesaid County, duly commissioned and sworn, Joseph Barnett aged Eighty two years, resident of Anderson township in said County, who being first duly sworn according to law, doth on his oath make the following declaration, in order to obtain the benefit of the Act of Congress passed July 7th 1838.

I was born in Baltimore County Maryland on or about the year 1771 and have resided in Anderson Township Hamilton Co Ohio for forty years past - I have no record of my age but always supposed myself to be about the age stated. My father was named Edward Barnett, my mother’s maiden name was Elizabeth Johnson, both of whom were natives of Maryland.

I enlisted in the Army of the United States at Baltimore County Maryland in the year 1792 for three years or during the war in Captain John Conn’s Company of Infantry commanded by Colo. Symmes - I served as a private in said Company, and was discharged from the service at Fort Washington near Cincinnati Ohio in the fall of the year 1795.

My first tour of duty after enlistment was to go with a detachment under command of Capt John Conn to Pittsburgh Pa where we arrived in about three weeks, thence by flat boats down the Ohio river to Fort Washington - this tour occupied about six weeks. I remained at Fort Washington two months when I was ordered on a tour of duty to Marietta Ohio for the purpose of protecting the inhabitants from the Indians who were hostile and troublesome at that time - we had several skirmishes with them, but no regular engagements while I was in service - The Company under command of Capt John Conn remained at Marietta about six months when they returned to Fort Washington where I remained until discharged.

I hereby relinquish every claim whatever to a pension or annuity except the present, and declare that my name is not on the pension roll of any agency in any state -

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year first above written
Joseph Barnett

We J.W. Hunter & James Frazier residents of Anderson township in the County aforesaid, hereby certify that we are well acquainted with Joseph Barnett who has subscribed and sworn to the above declaration, that we believe him to be Eighty two years of age, that he is reputed and believed in the community where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that we concur in that opinion -

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year first above written
J.W. Hunter
James Frazier

Also personally appeared James Frazier and J.W. Hunter residents of Anderson Township Hamilton Co Ohio who being duly sworn say that they were present and saw Joseph Barnett sign and acknowledge the above declaration - That he is reputed and believed in the community where he resides to have been a soldier of the Revolution, and that they concur in that opinion.

Sworn to and subscribed the day and year first above written
James Frazier
J.W. Hunter

Andrea [illegible], Ohio
March 26th 1853
The foregoing affidavits were taken, sworn to and subscribed before me -
Elisha Hunt, Notary Public
